title: What are the best conversion rates? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the request, even though it’s impossible to answer this question without additional details, I’ll try: conversion rates vary dramatically between different products, different media, channels, acquisition tools, pages and funnels, plus, most of the time conversion averages are industry based. That means that every sector has a different range of optimal conversion rates, let’s say, for an email open rate or landing page CR%. Unbounce publishes dozens of studies and articles every year, here’s an excerpt: So what’s the average landing page conversion rate? We’ve analyzed lead generation landing pages across 10 different industries (with a total of 74,551,421 visitors), and the average landing page conversion rate was 4.02%. The lowest-converting industry is higher education at 2.6%, and the highest-converting industry is vocational studies & job training at 6.1%. Remember, that 4.02% is just an average of the different industries, just for landing pages; it’s a starting point that you can use to orient yourself, but it’s not useful or directly applicable to a real project. You have to figure out your own metrics and extract your own data sets. Here’s a visual representation:  One of the many easily available sources: What is the Average Landing Page Conversion Rate By Industry? - If you want to learn more about the art of landing pages and how to optimize your conversions, these answers may help: • What are the best things to do to increase the conversion (get more sales) of my landing page? • Do you need a high converting landing page for your business? • How long should a web landing page be? • Where should you keep the most valuable content on a landing page, the top left or the top right? Most heat map studies show top left as the most "viewed" area but it seems like most websites keep the important things on the top right side. • When should you use your website home page as a landing page for a product? And when not to? • How much traffic should you have before introducing a heatmap on your website or landing page? - Landing Page Reviews: • Q: We just launched this website and we want to get your opinion on how we can improve the design . Do you have any suggestion? • Q: What are some feedback on my project's landing page?

One which delivers a positive ROI. Most make the mistake of judging their metrics against a percentage reported to be the industry standard for that format. But each situation is unique, and that only tells part of the picture. For instance, let’s say you have two ecommerce product pages. Page A converts 2% of it’s traffic into a sale, while Page B converts 5%. So page B is better, right? Not necessarily. Say the product on Page A has a profit margin of $100, and the one on Page B has a earns $25 for unit. Assume 100 people visit each of those pages. Page A would earn $200 in profit. Page B would only earn $125, even though the conversion rate is higher. So what you need to do is figure out your cost per conversion and break even point. Of course this is easier said than done, especially when you are measuring conversions that aren’t direct sales. What you need to do for that is investigate your funnel and attribute a value for each step in the process. Also, don’t forget about lifetime value. Sometimes it makes sense to even lose money on an initial sale if you can make up for it in future transactions. I hope that helps.

Which conversion rate are you indicating? If the indication is regarding Email, then 2.5–5 per cent will be considered a success. These days readers do not pay attention to their emails; therefore, it has become arduous to convert them as customers. If the email is innovative and attracts customers, then anything above 2.5 to 5 per cent will be considered a success. Note that companies email address will play a critical role here; spamming the readers with the bulk of emails will lead to disaster and catastrophes for the business. Add value for the reader; let them select their plans or products; do not market your products aggressively; one day or other they will buy from you.

100% is a very good conversion rate. Not realistic but very good. The problem is not knowing what part of the system you are in when measuring. Also need to know the product or service, and the media. Email, FB, online, snail mail and every other media will have different conversion rates for initial prospects versus previous buyers. The segmentation of the prospects and the message also affect conversion. With all those variables, we add in the generic “only about 3% of people are ready to buy at any given time. “ And don’t forget those who see your ad, online or offline, and have a conversion rate to action. Those who take the action may be sent to a webpage. That is another conversion. Those who actually order instead of leaving are another conversion rate. The simple answer to your question is: it’s complicated! Hope that helps!

That’s a tough question to answer. It is dependent on a number of factors including your industry and your core conversion goals. Amazon has a 75% conversion rate for Prime members. Some websites are doing well to get a 2% conversion rate. What type of website are you running?

At GoGoChimp we’ve achieved 47.17% of all traffic to request a quote for services and close 80% opt in rate for a lead gen. In truth it depends on the niche, traffic source and the offer. I go through the three most important things you need to get super-high conversion rates in this video:

Conversion rates vary across industries, with averages quoted at between 2–4%. My colleague wrote an article on just this subject, as the rate you achieve depends very much on the tactics you employ: How to Improve Ecommerce Conversion Rates - Don't settle for 2% Hope this is helpful?
